Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: New York Covid-19 Chronicle and Oral History Archive

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The COVID-19 pandemic is the gravest public health crisis the United States has faced since the Influenza pandemic of 1918, but it will not be the last. Disaster research is often by necessity retrospective, providing accounts of past actions and ongoing recoveries. The temporal profile of the COVID-19 pandemic presents an opportunity for social research in the middle of an unfolding crisis, providing contemporaneous insights into risk perception and sensemaking under duress, community and organizational resilience, transformations in social structure, and real time adaptations to severe economic and social dislocations. Concentrating on New York City, this project will create a contemporaneous record of the city’s battle with COVID-19 across the epidemic curve. New York is a critical site for understanding the course of this pandemic because it was an early epicenter of the disease in the U.S., because it has a robust municipal emergency management system with deep experience of past disasters, health-related and otherwise, and because it is home to one of the nation’s strongest urban healthcare systems. The project will provide real time findings about New York City that will be relevant to jurisdictions in earlier phases along the arc of the pandemic, thus assisting other governmental leaders in planning effective responses. This project will also rigorously document the COVID-19 emergency to better understand how it is unfolding, to better inform the recovery, and to learn lessons that will aid our fight against the next pandemic and other extreme events. These findings will be critical to leaders at all levels of government so as to promote the safety and security of U.S. residents in the years ahead.

The current COVID-19 pandemic challenges community and organizational resilience and necessitates transformations in social structure. To analyze these changes, this project combines three approaches to data gathering that capture the evolving and multi-dimensional impact of the COVID-19 crisis on New Yorkers. First, a survey of 1,000 people will track shifts in stress responses, helping behaviors, social isolation, and resilience. Demographic data gathered from the survey will inform and refine recruitment of new participants. The sample will be stratified across different scales of the response: everyday New Yorkers, frontline workers--including first and second responders, critical infrastructure and other essential workers--and strategic level decision makers, managers, and planners. These results will be complemented by data from a diary study with 500 participants, and a sequence of oral history interviews with 200 narrators at expanding intervals, to produce a rich longitudinal perspective on the relationship between micro shifts in attitudes and relations, and macro transformations in urban structures and dynamics. Findings will inform sociological theories regarding the relationship between micro- and macro-levels of social organization, disaster preparedness and response, risk perception and social stress.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to create a contemporaneous record of New York City’s experience of the COVID-19 pandemic using survey data, in-depth interviews, and written diaries. Our sample of respondents was stratified into three tiers defined by their occupational location within the pandemic: 1) institutional decision-makers, public health officials, and emergency managers working to fight the pandemic on a strategic level while their direct exposure to contagion risk was relatively low; 2) frontline workers including first and second responders like paramedics, doctors, and nurses, critical infrastructure workers, grocery and delivery workers with high direct risk of exposure to the virus; and 3) New Yorkers who fell under stay-at-home orders and were either out of work or able/required to work from home.

In the first wave of in-depth interviews, we aimed to learn more about how New Yorkers sought information about the spread of SARS-CoV-2, about public health measures being implemented to curb the pandemic, and about how to keep themselves and people close to them safe. We also asked about how respondents were complying with public health measures like lockdowns, social distancing, and masking. We inquired about how workers and workplaces were adapting to the pandemic, particularly the shift to remote work, which had never been attempted at this scale before. In instances in which workers were directly involved in fighting the pandemic (especially paramedics, doctors, and nurses, but also contact tracers and public officials) we developed more focused questions on how their work adapted to the challenges of medical surge and diagnosis and treatment of a novel disease. We asked about how home life was changing, particularly with regard to changes in family configuration and childcare. Our questions also explored social life and community sustenance, including volunteerism and participation in social movements.

In the second wave of interviews, which unfolded throughout the second surge of the pandemic in New York City, we shifted focus to examine how and whether the coping strategies people had generated to deal with the initial phase of the pandemic had held up. We also asked about what impacts they observed in their neighborhoods or communities, how they navigated a limited re-engagement with the social world as lockdown measures eased in New York City in the summer of 2020, and how they experienced the social unrest that erupted that same summer where it intersected with their experience of the pandemic. Towards the end of the second wave, as conditions again changed, we asked about vaccination decisions and the turbulent political environment leading up to and following the 2020 election, again where that intersected with their experiences of the pandemic.

The ultimate goal of this project is to build an archive consisting of video-recorded interviews with nearly 200 New Yorkers from all walks of life and nearly 1,000 diary entries from people who lived through the peak at one of the epicenters of the pandemic in the United States, providing testimony of how the pandemic transformed the city, but also serving as a rich source of information on the strengths and weaknesses of the public health response to the pandemic. This archive, which will be housed and publicly available in the Columbia University Libraries, will be a resource for policy-makers, humanities and social sciences scholars, artists, and other individuals seeking to engage with the pandemic through memory and interpretation.
